meeting_annotations.transcript: but we don't think about okay how does molecule C interfere with that how does it move out of the way. meeting_annotations.speaker: Caitlin Davis
meeting_annotations.transcript: So we have a microscope where we've monitored protein RNA binding partners who are part of the spliceosome and we we can do exactly what you describe. So label one partner with one fluorophore and the other with another and monitor fret between them and we use temperature perturbations to get on and off rates as well as binding affinities and then mapping that to regions of the cell. So we see differences in affinity in vitro in the cytoplasm and in the nucleus and I do have some evidence for differences in droplets at least for motion into and out of the droplet at different temperatures. So it's something we can look at and we've built a three-color system to try and do assembly. But something I'm also interested is in the structure and the activity inside the droplets and so PFK for example is thought to form a filament structure and that's been seen in vitro but not in cells. So using infrared spectroscopy or infrared imaging we're hoping to look at the actual structure in in the droplets and then by using infrared labels in a region that is free of infrared modes monitor activity associated with those different structures. And then we use our perturbation techniques to cause phase separation to occur and look at changes in the activity. So we get kind of a spatial map of activity in the cell.

Then in the infrared you're unlimited in your probes right because you know we have basically two million vibrational spectra from 800 wave numbers out to 2000 wave numbers. You express these genetically in your cells and then do single particle tracking on them and you can do then mean squared displacements and all sorts of microrheology tricks to figure out crowding at different length scales.
